docTitle.titlePart:
Assessing optimized MR flow quantification sequences for different levels of flow encoding:
Preliminary Results

byline.docAuthor: M. S. Nair1'3, J. L. Duerk1'2, S. E. Rittgers3

byline.affiliation:

front.div:
Introduction A number of studies have reviewed the effects of higher order
derivatives of motion such as acceleration [1], differences in
encoding times [2,3], and errors due to increasing velocity
sensitivity [4] as contributing to the inaccuracies in MR derived
velocity measurements. These errors have in part compromised
the effectiveness of MR flow quantification techniques as a
clinical tool compared to ultrasound. One of the approaches that
can be used to rectify these errors is through pulse sequence
design in general, and optimized gradient waveform design in
specific.
Objective Our objective was to compare the velocity estimates obtained
using optimized gradient waveforms which 1) compensated
higher order motion moments such as acceleration, 2) encoded
both the spatial position and the velocity at the point of expansion
(POE), and 3) mapped velocities at different levels of flow
encodings (30째, 60째 , 90째 and 180째), to a known calibrated
physiological flow system.
Methods Gradient waveforms: Arbitrarily shaped gradient waveforms were
designed in Matlab (The Mathworks Inc., Natick, MA) using the
Gill-Murray-Wright algorithm for constrained quadratic
programming [5,6]. The designed gradient waveforms were
acceleration compensated, had identical POE to account for both
spatial and velocity misregistration artifacts, and had different
levels of flow encoding to interrogate effects of errors due to
increasing velocity sensitivity. The optimization constraints were
those imposed by the software and hardware limitations of the
MR system.
